pr_title: feat(broker): feel expressions for message correlation keys

timeline.message: feat(broker): feel expressions for message correlation keys

timeline.bodyText:
No need to create a new buffer for every correlation key. The buffer is copied in the calling method extractMessageCorrelationKeys().
We can use BufferUtil.wrapString() and put the buffer in extractedCorrelationKeys. wrapString() creates a new buffer of the given string.
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText:
Not sure whether I got you right here, BufferUtil.wrapString() also creates a new buffer.
I now made the following changes;

extractCorrelationKey will return a String
in extractedCorrelationKeys this String is wrapped exactly once

If you had something different in mind, please let me know. Not sure I understand the buffers yet.
replies.author: pihme

timeline.bodyText:
Why do we have a special failure message if the result is an array?
Does it provides more value for the user than the other message The value must be either a string or a number, but was ...?
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: probably not, will remove this case
replies.author: pihme

timeline.bodyText:
As of today, this check will never be true. The evaluation result type number is of class BigDecimal.
I think it is safe to just call evaluationResult.getNumber().longValue().
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText:
That's good you mention this.
My intention was to make sure that numbers with fractions don't get converted to Strings.
I cannot imagine a case in which a value of "42.5" is a valid correlation key.
The only case I could imagine it is if you have something like an article number with a dot in it (e.g. "178.452") and then for some reason it appears as a number rather than a string in the message. Still it is far-fetched.
I am slightly uncomfortable about the getNumber().longValue approach because BigDecimal.of(54.5).longValue() == 54, so I wouldn't catch the fraction and thus a potential developer error.
replies.author: pihme

timeline.bodyText: No need to create a new interface. We can use the common interface Function<EvaluationResult, T>.
timeline.author: saig0
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,15 @@

+
+public interface ExpressionResultHandler<T> {
+
+  T handleEvaluationResult(final EvaluationResult evaluationResult);

timeline.bodyText: In addition, we should also verify that no static value is used as a correlation key (e.g. foo). It must be always as expression (e.g. =bar).
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: wil be done as part of #4048
replies.author: pihme

timeline.bodyText: Why do we need to change the default locale?
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText:
It was needed because one of the error messages formats the value that was the result of the evaluation expression. This value is formatted locale-dependent.
I now removed this from the test and instead set the locale where the message is generated:
String.format(Locale.US, "Failed to extra...
replies.author: pihme

timeline.bodyText:
I'm a bit unsure about the test. I see that it makes sense to verify this behavior in a unit test because writing an integration test is more effort.
But the test makes some assumptions about the dependent classes that are not true for the current system. EvaluationResult returns always a BigDecimal instead of an Integer, Double, etc. I think we can reduce the test cases a bit.
timeline.author: saig0
saig0

timeline.bodyText: Instead of externalizing the behavior here, we can also create a specific method in ExpressionProcessor. Then all expression related logic (here: extract string or long as string) can be in one place and it is easy to have consistent behavior. What do you think?
timeline.author: saig0

replies.bodyText:
Here I have the strongest objections.
To be precise, my objections are not about the conversion logic, but about the side effects.
In the old code, whenever I wanted to get a String, I had to pass in a BpmnStepContext and as a side effect an Incident might be raised. I was very surprised by that.
If I added a new method to expression processor, then this method would need to get a MessageCorrelationKeyContect and again the side effect would be a surprise. Plus, I doubt this method can be reused in many places. But I might be wrong.
I extracted it into a class, because it made it easier for me to write the test. Before that I had it as a methd in CatchEventBehavior. But when I wrote the unit test, I had to make so many things just to call the constructor, that the dedicated class clearly was the better options.
I don't care much about where the class lives. I hid it here, because I didn't think it could be resued. If it can be reused, I would probably move it out and alongside ExpressionResultTypeVerifyingIncidentRaisingHandler.
To come back to your initital intent: I think the ExpressionProcessor would make more sense, if we can factor out the side effects (raising incidents, or exceptions). So in an ideal world it would return an Either<Result, ErroMessage>. But I didn't want to make this change given the pending refactoring.
replies.author: pihme
